componenttext: $10 million incremental. Okay. Got it. And then you talked about green shoots on light non-resi, any signs of moderation or any concerns in the heavy non-resi?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2021
componenttextpreview: No, not particularly. In fact, I would say, not at all. The heavy non-res has continued to be really quite good. And part of what I'm encouraged by, for example, the energy portion of that, as you know, has actually not been particularly good. So it's bee
componenttext: No, not particularly. In fact, I would say, not at all. The heavy non-res has continued to be really quite good. And part of what I'm encouraged by, for example, the energy portion of that, as you know, has actually not been particularly good. So it's been more driven by warehousing, data warehousing, et cetera. As you may recall in some of the commentary I was sharing before, we're seeing more activity in West Texas on energy than we've seen for a while. At the same time, for example, the Port Arthur LNG facility that's been on some degree of hold for a while, our understanding, spectral is really anticipating some bid refreshing on that in this quarter. And we may see some activity there as early as Q1 2022, not job that we've won at this point, but still nonetheless, seeing that type of activity on heavy, we actually think it's quite attractive, Josh.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David MacGregor with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David MacGregor with Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2021
componenttextpreview: Congrats to the team. I guess, I wanted to just ask about pricing here, and certainly, the outlook for 2022 is obviously very encouraging. But I guess I'm trying to understand what happened in 3Q, and I fully appreciate that you had a mix benefit or mix l
componenttext: Congrats to the team. I guess, I wanted to just ask about pricing here, and certainly, the outlook for 2022 is obviously very encouraging. But I guess I'm trying to understand what happened in 3Q, and I fully appreciate that you had a mix benefit or mix liability, I guess, with the base stone and the excess fill material. But you were tracking at 3.4% coming through the first half and you dropped down to 2.2% on an organic basis. So I'm hoping you can sort of give us some sense of what organic growth in pricing might have looked like, excluding the base stone and the excess fill material and start with that, if you would, please?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, look, I think a quick answer is, we've been very comfortably in those zones that we had talked about earlier. And I think when -- again, David, if it's 900 -- if it's almost 1 million tons of bill and Phil largely looked at broadly as almost a wa
componenttext: Yes. No, look, I think a quick answer is, we've been very comfortably in those zones that we had talked about earlier. And I think when -- again, David, if it's 900 -- if it's almost 1 million tons of bill and Phil largely looked at broadly as almost a waste product. Obviously, we sold it for front because we did have in the books for anything, but it is a bill product. And if you're looking at what was a fairly significant movement on base, particularly in that Raleigh market, again, of all the things that I've worried at night about aggregate pricing is not on my list. And those are purely and simply those are the drivers. The other thing -- and I know your question was on organic, but I do think it's important to keep in mind when you look at it all rolled up, stone pricing in the acquired Tiller operations are about $5 a ton lower than our heritage number. So again, when you do an all-in number with that, it clearly has optically a dilutive effect. And then when you feather in nearly 1 million tons of funds, again, it will have an optical effect. But I think, to your point, the midyear, I think really did underscore the strength of the market. To give you a sense of what we saw in the East division and this really means in the Carolinas, was $1 a ton up on clean stone effective July 1, and even $0.50 on base effective July 1. And then Southwest, we saw -- in North Texas, up $0.50 to $0.75 a ton on September 1. In Austin, up $1 a ton and around Hunter stone, which is in new Broncos, $0.50 to up $1 a ton and then at Garwood, up $1 a ton on August 1. So I think all those at least in the way that I'm watching it and measuring the cadence, David, give me a high degree of confidence in what we're anticipating next year that and probably more importantly, together with conversations we've had with our customers. So I hope that helps.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just to be clear, as you look at that organic number, excluding the base stone and the excess fill material, you're saying that pricing would have been up sequentially, excluding those items, your price to be up sequentially?
componenttext: Yes. So just to be clear, as you look at that organic number, excluding the base stone and the excess fill material, you're saying that pricing would have been up sequentially, excluding those items, your price to be up sequentially?

componenttext: Yes, it will.

componenttext: Was there anything different in terms of the initial third quarter traction rates on these third quarter price increases that just comparing that with prior price increases? Is there anything that was maybe different this time?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2021 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2021
componenttextpreview: No, not really. The only thing that I would say is, it's probably consistent this time. Whenever you do in midyear, you're only going to actually see a very limited portion of those go in the year and input you put it. I mean, historically, what I would h
componenttext: No, not really. The only thing that I would say is, it's probably consistent this time. Whenever you do in midyear, you're only going to actually see a very limited portion of those go in the year and input you put it. I mean, historically, what I would have said, if you did a midyear truly on July 1 or June 30, if you got 20% or 25% of it in the year in which you put it in, you'd be fortunate. So really, it's more of a play into the following year.

componenttextpreview: Shannon, thank you so much, and thank you all for joining today's earnings conference call. To conclude, our strong third quarter results underpinned by our record-setting safety, operational and financial performance reinforce our confidence in Martin Ma
componenttext: Shannon, thank you so much, and thank you all for joining today's earnings conference call. To conclude, our strong third quarter results underpinned by our record-setting safety, operational and financial performance reinforce our confidence in Martin Marietta's opportunities to sort to a sustainable future and maximize stakeholder value. We look forward to sharing our fourth quarter and full year 2021 results in February. As always, we're available for any follow-up questions you may have. Thank you for your time and continued support of Martin Marietta. Please stay safe and healthy. Bye-bye.
